instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Webcam not recognized on otherwise functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
threads.message: I have a 2015 Retina 13" board that's working completely fine except it does not recognize the webcam. All ports (USB, SD Card, Thunderbolt, etc. are working.) There was a little bit of corrosion in multiple spots. There was a very small amount near the webcam connector, but the pins look completely unaffected. I've tried multiple webcams with no change. I've tested all voltages and found none only <SIGNAL>PP0V675_CAM_VREF</SIGNAL> missing. Does anyone know how this is created? It seems like it's coming from <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>. Maybe <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> was damaged or I'm missing a signal that triggers <SIGNAL>PP0V675_CAM_VREF</SIGNAL>? On a known good board, <SIGNAL>PP0V675_CAM_VREF</SIGNAL> is on as soon as the board gets power. No webcam needs to be plugged in. Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: Webcam not recognized on otherwise functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
threads.message: First test pins 1-6 on diode mode of cam connector.

threads.title: Webcam not recognized on otherwise functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
threads.message:
Ok, so I replaced <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP0V675_CAM_VREF</SIGNAL> is present now and the camera is recognized but there is no image and the green light is just blinking steadily.
Pins 1-6 (with cable plugged in:

1 0
2 0.377
3 0.377
4 0
5 0.379
6 0.378

Also, instead of being in the 0.275 range in diode mode, <SIGNAL>PP1V2_CAM</SIGNAL> is around 0.029. It's still producing 1.194 volts though. I put some voltage through it but can't find any obvious shorts or issues.

threads.title: Webcam not recognized on otherwise functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
threads.message:
As far as I can see that 1V2 is generated by <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and goes nowhere else. I'd say <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> was dead or you killed it while soldering.
Also did you try with a know good camera, could also very well be that the cam in the LCD is dead.
